body:
Thanks for the report. Can you try the development version? 

- The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/tag/nightly) page has pre-built archives for Linux/Windows/macOS. 
- Check `:version` to confirm that you are using the latest version.

Note that some servers won't respect the LSP regarding when a null response is allowed, and in those cases we shouldn't accommodate invalid responses. Either we ask the respective language server to follow the protocol, or create an issue in [the specs](https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol) for clarity on how to deal with these scenarios.

We have seen this happen in the past: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26957

Also it seems like this is related to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27148, and I think @wookayin gave a great response about our stand here: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27148#discussion_r1463344910

> Also it seems like this is related to #27148, and I think @wookayin gave a great response about our stand here: [#27148 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27148#discussion_r1463344910)

I'm sorry I missed that issue when I tried to find related issue.

I agree and I will take a closer look on both Omnisharp and their csharp-language-server-protocol to see if I can find the bug and open an issue there instead
This has been closed since a request for information has not been answered for 30 days. It can be reopened when the requested information is provided.

performed_via_github_app.name: GitHub Actions
performed_via_github_app.description: Automate your workflow from idea to production

body: @teast Did you manage to figure out where this issue originated from?
Nevermind I was too quick in my reading https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-roslyn/issues/2574

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27148#discussion_r1463344910 was rightly rejected because it silently ignores the error.

But it seems perfectly reasonable to throw a readable error message here stating the LSP server is erroneously returning nil. The rest of the code in rpc.lua is doing similar sanity checking, for example giving good error messages if the LSP server returns a number, which is clearly also invalid. We should not silently ignore these issues, but we also shouldn't just crash inside a random NeoVim rpc.lua file because of dereferencing a nil.

issue.title: fix(lsp): check for nil response from server

repository.name: neovim
repository.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

issue.body:
This fixes #27395. OmniSharp (and possibly other LSP servers) can sometimes return a nil value, which rpc.lua chokes on with this error message:

```
Error executing luv callback:                                                                                                                                                                              
...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:410: attempt to index local 'decoded' (a nil value)                                                                                                      
stack traceback:                                                                                                                                                                                                     
        ...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:410: in function 'handle_body'                                                                                                                   
        ...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:761: in function 'handle_body'                                                                                                                   
        ...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:267: in function <...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:251>
```

We should not crash, no matter what the LSP server throws at us. Note that #27148 would be even worse; silently ignoring the error. Rather, we should provide a proper error message stating the LSP server gave us something invalid, so that it is clear that the error is with the LSP server, rather than being a crash inside NeoVim runtime scripts. We are already doing a lot of validation in rpc.lua, it's just that nil was being overlooked here.

By adding a check first that `decoded` isn't nil, we end up falling back to the else case:

```
self:on_error(M.client_errors.INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE, decoded)
```

which is going to correctly inform the user that the LSP server is broken, not NeoVim.

issue.title: Recent versions of OmniSharp cause `LSP[bugged-ls]: Error INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE: nil`

repository.name: neovim
repository.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

issue.body:
### Problem

It's not clear (to me) whose fault it is, but recent versions of OmniSharp (the C# language server) are not compatible with Neovim. After starting up nvim, OmniSharp LSP gets started, and seconds later, I see this, at the bottom of nvim window. Neovim and OmniSharp otherwise seem to behave normally, and the error doesn't appear to reoccur after startup.

```
LSP[bugged-ls]: Error INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE: nil
```

The occurrence of this error seems to correlate with the size of the project. With a test project of a single file, I never saw the error. With 2 files, it is rare. With 100 files, it almost always occurred.

There is a bug report in OmniSharp repo, about the same thing: https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-roslyn/issues/2574 - but it's not apparent that either anyone is working or it, or that it's even OmniSharp's problem.

Could it be that OmniSharp is behaving according to LSP spec, but nvim fails to understand its valid messages? After all, this issue doesn't appear to happen on Helix or VSCode.

Or else, if OmniSharp is not behaving by the spec, then we should point out what exactly nvim dislikes about OmniSharp's messages.

### Steps to reproduce using "nvim -u minimal_init.lua"

1. Create a new C# application: `mkdir omnitest; cd omnitest; dotnet new console; touch .editorconfig`
2. Add some files with Bash: `for i in $(seq 1 100); do echo -e "namespace Test;\nclass Stuff$i { public static int Add(int x, int y) => $i + x - y; }" > Stuff$i.cs ; done`
3. Start `nvim -u ~/minimal_init.lua Program.cs`, wait for < 10 seconds, and observe the error down where the `:` commands of Vim normally are.

```lua
--- CHANGE THESE
local pattern = 'cs'

-- Follow this guide to build a working version of OmniSharp:
-- https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-roslyn/issues/2574#issuecomment-2246390939
-- local cmd = {'/path/to/omnisharp-roslyn/bin/Release/OmniSharp.Stdio.Driver/net6.0/OmniSharp', '--languageserver', '-v'}
local cmd = {'OmniSharp', '--languageserver', '-v'} -- the default one is failing

-- Add files/folders here that indicate the root of a project
local root_markers = {'.git', '.editorconfig'}
-- Change to table with settings if required
local settings = vim.empty_dict()

vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('FileType', {
  pattern = pattern,
  callback = function(args)
    local match = vim.fs.find(root_markers, { path = args.file, upward = true })[1]
    local root_dir = match and vim.fn.fnamemodify(match, ':p:h') or nil
    vim.lsp.start({
      name = 'bugged-ls',
      cmd = cmd,
      root_dir = root_dir,
      settings = settings
    })
  end
})

vim.lsp.set_log_level("debug")
```

### Expected behavior

As written in https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-roslyn/issues/2574#issuecomment-2246390939
one can "fix" the problem by reverting a single file in OmniSharp repository. When I do, the error disappears.
I've attached a log of the "reverted" case, for comparison.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.11.0-dev-578+gb04b263e1f

### Language server name/version

OmniSharp, newer than b2e64c6

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Log file

https://gist.github.com/cizra/e0b5b1c019bd56cd6d2304c547cd53d4
